title: 107_s1733
content: The Act titled "Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001" establishes an interoperable law enforcement and intelligence data system with name matching capacity and training. The "Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001" requires the development of a unified electronic data system within 18 months to provide immediate access to relevant information for visa issuance and alien admissibility. The system must have name matching capacity across different databases. The unified electronic database must store names in different fields, be searchable based on linguistically sensitive criteria, offer user support, involve private sector firms in development, use commercially available platforms, and be continuously improved based on experience and technological advancements. The unified electronic database must be searchable using linguistically sensitive algorithms that account for variations in name formats and transliterations, and incorporate advanced linguistic, mathematical, statistical, and anthropological research methods for at least 4 high-priority languages designated by key government officials. The unified electronic data system must provide easily accessible information about names in different languages and a means for users to communicate with experts. Interim reports must be submitted every 6 months by key government officials. The Secretary of State, Attorney General, Secretary of the Treasury, Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, and Director of Central Intelligence must submit reports every 6 months on implementing the requirements of the Act. The Director of Central Intelligence must complete a survey and issue a report within 60 days, and guidelines within 120 days of the Act's enactment. The Director of Intelligence must issue guidelines within 120 days of the Act's enactment and submit reports every 6 months on implementing the requirements. Authorization of necessary appropriations is also provided. Consultation with various government officials is required for the development and implementation of the data system. The Director of Intelligence must consult with government officials to develop and implement a data system that follows a technology standard. Information in the system should be easily accessible to Foreign Service officers and Federal agents. The Secretary of State, the Attorney General, and the Director of Central Intelligence will establish procedures to limit access to intelligence information in the data system.
